<div class=WordSection1>

<h1><span style='mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Project: MESSENGERS
AND NAVIGATIONAL PROGRAMMING<o:p></o:p></span></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal>This project is developing a new programming paradigm,
called <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>Navigational Programming</i>, for
distributed systems based on the principles of autonomously migrating
processes, called <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>Messengers</i>. Each
Messenger is able to migrate among nodes of a local area network using explicit
hop statements, which support strong migration. Unlike mobile agents used for a
variety of services on the Internet, the MESSENGERS system is intended for
general-purpose scientific computing. </p>

<p>Some of the advantages of migrating processes, as compared to stationary
message-passing processes, are highlighted in the following <a
href="file:///C:\Users\bic\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Word\papers\summary.pdf">Project
Summary</a>. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in'><o:p> </o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in'>There are two independent versions
of MESSENGERS: MESSENGERS-I, and MESSENGERS-C, where "I" stands for
"interpreted", and "C" stands for "compiled". The
MESSENGERS-C is faster than MESSENGERS-I, but MESSENGERS-I has a Virtual Time
support. </p>
